definitions.definition: a special right or advantage that a particular person or group of people has

examples.text: Education should be a universal right and not a privilege.
You can enjoy all the benefits and privileges of club membership.
Try not to abuse the privilege of being allowed more freedom.
Club members have special privileges, like being allowed to use the swimming pool.
Prisoners' behaviour is controlled by a system of punishments and privileges.
Real choice in education remains the privilege of the middle classes.
Top party officials were accused of granting privileges to their friends and family.
He was accused of abusing his diplomatic privileges.

definitions.definition: the rights and advantages that rich and powerful people in a society have

examples.text: As a member of the nobility, his life had been one of wealth and privilege.

definitions.definition: something that you are proud and lucky to have the opportunity to do

examples.text: I hope to have the privilege of working with them again.
It was a great privilege to hear her sing.
It is a great privilege to be attending this conference.
She had the rare privilege of a viewing of his private art collection.
I was given the dubious privilege of organizing the summer fair.

definitions.definition: a special right to do or say things without being punished

examples.text: parliamentary privilege *(= the special right of members of parliament to say particular things without risking legal action)*
**breach of privilege** *(= the breaking of rules about what a member of parliament can say and do)*

wordOrigin: Middle English: via Old French from Latin privilegium ‘bill or law affecting an individual’, from privus ‘private’ + lex, leg- ‘law’.
